abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Cotton Sector Reform
            Project for Benin were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: using investment lending in tandem
            with budget support to implement difficult reforms may be
            more effective than each instrument alone. The project under
            review experienced that reforms are extremely difficult to
            implement within a sector as strategic and as politically
            sensitive as cotton. Even if it is clearly stated initially,
            Government commitment can hardly be taken for granted on a
            long period of time, unless irreversible steps are taken at
            the beginning of the reform process, which was not the case
            in the Benin reform process. The privatization of National
            Company for agricultural production was finally completed
            under joint support of specific investment lending and
            budget support. Budget support can signal and facilitate
            commitment to reforms. Strong sector teams from the
            investment side are, however, needed to lead an effective
            policy dialogue. Institutional development and structural
            reforms should be outward looking and keep an eye on
            evolving global developments. The project under review and
            the underlying cotton sector reform were affected by
            decisions of key stakeholders driven by internal struggles
            and the political economy of the national cotton sector.
            Evidence based analysis highlighting the performance of
            alternative approaches followed in the region could have
            improved decision making. The Bank is well suited to provide
            such kind of input as shown by the recently completed
            comparative analysis of Organization and Performance of
            African Cotton Sectors (World Bank 2008). The project was
            further affected by developments on international commodity
            and financial markets. Designs need to be forward looking,
            anticipate such external effects and be flexible enough to adapt.
